Since there's a good number of you right now, let's start
So, lets start with what HTML is first. It's essential to know these basics to do any kind of web development.
HTML is the standard markup language for creating Web pages.
<@U5CT7AE79|samarthb> has joined the channel
Kyu re yaha bhi suru ho gaya
It stands for Hypertext Markup Language .
So what's a markup language and how is it different from a programming language?

Markup languages are designed for the processing, definition and presentation of text.
They are designed not for general purpose programming, but for processing or presentation of text.
A simple HTML doc would look like this:
<@U52KA1B41|aneesh297> uploaded a file: <https://ieeespwd.slack.com/files/aneesh297/F5CT90CR5/sample_html_doc.html|Sample HTML doc>

file.name: Sample_HTML_doc.html
file.title: Sample HTML doc
file.preview_highlight:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
<head>
<title>Page Title</title>
</head>

text: You can create and edit HTML documents using a simple text editor like Notepad. Just don't forget to save it as a .html file.
Any doubts so far?
I'll clarify what each of those parts of the sample code mean in a moment
Uh is anybody online?

No doubts

Okay cool
yes......no doubts so far
So
The HTML document itself begins with <html> and ends with </html>.
The visible part of the HTML document is between <body> and </body>.
These things are called elements.

An HTML element usually consists of a start tag and end tag, with the content inserted in between:
<tagname>Content goes here...</tagname>

For example, the paragraph tag:
<p>Paragraph content</p>
In the body, if we want  to have headings, we use any of the <h1> to <h6> tags.
Where h1 indicates the most important heading and has the largest font size.
<h1> Heading </h1>
h2 will have smaller size is it?
yes
Now coming to attributes.
Attributes provide additional information about HTML elements.
what does it mean by the visible part?? the tag title wont b visible? its out of the body
Visible on the browser after running i suppose
No not the tag. The contents of the tag is visible on the browser.
is it more like the webpage name??
In other words, you'd put the any of the parts that are actually going to appear on the webpage in the body section
No. Whatever you see in the browser was coded within the body part.
okay!! thnx
gj: yes exactly
okay . about attributes. All HTML elements can have attributes.
for example, if you want to display an image, you use the <img></img> tag.
*<img> tag
What do u have inside it? the image name?
<img> name </img>?
So to mention which file you want to use, you mention the image name as an attribute
<img src="pic_mountain.jpg" alt="Mountain View" style="width:304px;height:228px;">
So src="pic_mountain.jpg" is an attribute.
src? alt?
Alternate text.
Source.
src is the name of the image file.
Is it necessary to give width and height ??

The alt attribute provides an alternate text for an image, if the user for some reason cannot view it (because of slow connection, an error in the src attribute, or if the user uses a screen reader). (Not that important)
if we place mouse on image, text shown is given by alt right?
"Is it necessary to give width and height ?? "No not necessarily, but you can reformat it to your specification using the width and height attributes
Coming to the style attribute.
Setting the style of an HTML element, can be done with the style attribute.
You can use this attribute for most elements.
Usually, we avoid explicitly mentioning the style for each element and try to use an external document called a StyleSheet (CSS) to determine the style of our elements.
<tagname style="property:value;">
The property is a CSS property. The value is a CSS value.
CSS = cascading style sheets. Sagar will cover this in a while
So lets take some style examples.
Lets say you want a different background color other than the plain borin white.
You can use <body style="background-color:powderblue;">
Or for header text: <h1 style="color:blue;">This is a heading</h1>
paragraph text: <p style="color:red;">This is a paragraph.</p>
Suppose you want to change text alignment of the heading: <h1 style="text-align:center;">Centered Heading</h1>
There are a lot of style attributes like these. I can't cover them all obviously. You can easily look it up online. We'll share a few resources later
What if we to change multiple style properties?
You use semicolons (;) to separate them in style attribute.
For example, <h1 style="text-align:center; color: red;">Centered Heading</h1>
Are there many kinds of tags?
yes

rahul: Yes there are many kinds of tags. Not for the things you mentioned but for making lists, text boxes, buttons, images, check boxes, radio buttons etc
Now, you may notice that "Are there many kinds of tags?" is highlighted as a link. This can be done using the <a> or the link tag.

HTML links are defined with the <a> tag:
<a href="https://www.google.com">This is a link</a>
href is the link address attribute
Okay
And "This is a link" is what you would view on the screen

But it's not feasible or even required to memorise all these tags all at once. Just remember the basic ones. Search online when need arises.

Each tag also has it's own set of attributes. So it's impossible to remember everything!
To help with styling, we have something known as a class attribute.
The HTML class attribute makes it possible to define equal styles for elements with the same class name.
Can we also post sound clips?
So for example we could define the style for a <h1> and <p> tag at once by assigning them to the same class.
yes you can.
Can you please clear the term attribute

div stands for?
<div> is used to separate the code into blocks. Nothing more than that

Okay so Rahul's doubt : What exactly are attributes?

Attributes are extra pieces of information about html tags. They define some properties of tags.

eg. in `<h1 align="centre">Sample Page</h1>`

h1 is the HTML tag.
align is an attribute(or property) of that tag.
centre is the value of the attribute align
And how do we style the components of a class?

text: *mentioned
We can print lists using several different tags.

An unordered list starts with the <ul> tag. Each list item starts with the <li> tag.
The list items will be marked with bullets (small black circles) by default:
For example:
here again you use styles. ex: <ul style="color:blue;">
*you can use
You can change the type of bullet by using list-style-type style property

An ordered list starts with the <ol> tag. Each list item starts with the <li> tag.
The list items will be marked with numbers by default:
Ex:
The type attribute of the <ol> tag, defines the type of the list item marker:
<ol type="A"> 	The list items will be numbered with uppercase letters
Lists can also be nested:
Any doubts so far?

Okay
Moving on to forms.
After this sagar will teach you guys about CSS.
The HTML <form> element defines a form that is used to collect user input:
An HTML form contains form elements.
Form elements are different types of input elements, like text fields, checkboxes, radio buttons, submit buttons, and more.
The <input> element is the most important form element.
The <input> element can be displayed in several ways, depending on the type attribute. Ex: radio-button, text submit
<input type="text"> defines a one-line input field for text input:

Okay so I'll be taking over now!
There are many more HTML tags but we'll won't cover them, We'll use them when needed
Now onto CSS
CSS stands for Cascading style Sheet.
So as developers, we should always strive to separate different components of our project.

In developing front end, there are two main things we should cocentrate on :
*Content* and *Formatting* of that content.
We use *html* to *structure* the content of our web page.
*CSS* to *format* them.

Okay so this is the power of CSS. It can format a simple HTML page into a good looking page!
I didnt get it
Now let me tell you exactly what CSS is, how we use it and I'll give a brief run through the code snippet I posted!
what did you not get?
<br> what is this? and in the last second line why type=submit?

The basic syntax of CSS include : 
1. Selector
2. property
3. Value
it should be type=text only right?
<br> is a line break. Think of it as a simple ENTER
*Selector* : Selects HTML elements to be formatted.
its a tag or what?
*Property* : The properties of the selected element to be altered
Yep
*Value* : The value of the property
Anything enclosed within a <> is a tage
*tag
A tag can have several attributes though.
so the body should end with </br> right
(Taken from the CSS file I posted)

Here, 
`body` is *selector*
`font-family`, `color`, `background` are *properties*
`tahoma`, `#FFFFFF`, `#0d1521` are *values*
The <br> tag is an empty tag which means that it has no end tag. ie. No need for </br>
oh ok....and the last second line..
That is in this part of CSS, we are formatting the body element of HTML document.
Submit?
what about it?
First we'll learn about the syntax to write *selectors*
that "type=submit" thing....it should be type=text only right
because "submit" is "text" only right
No. It creates a button called submit. Not a form field.
<https://www.w3schools.com/html/tryit.asp?filename=tryhtml_form_submit>
The source code is in this link. You can visualize it better now
See the above code. We've used `#choice` as selector. Now what does `#` mean?
Here `#choice` selects all elements whose `id` attribute has value `choice`
I think sagar must have answered this the css intro
ok got it....and style attributes are written in tag named "head"?
If you go back to out HTML document, you'll notice the `div` element has `id` set to `choice`. So that element will be selected and formatted
yep

Similary, you can use `.` to select an element with a specific `class` attribute.

Example : 
```
.hello{
}
```

Will select all elements with attribute class

`#lichoice:hover` is called a *psudo-selector*. It formats elements when they are in a particular _state_.
but li already comes under the id choice..so shouldnt it follow the #choice properties?

Example : In the HTML doc I sent, you'll notice the list elements change color when you move your mouse over them.

This is because, we have specified different formatting for `hover state` (ie. when mouse is over that element) and normal state(ie. when mouse is not over the element)

suyashghuge: Yes it is formatted using #choice properties also. In addition we are specifying some properties in #lichoice.

It's like inheritance. Child elements inherit properties of parents plus they have their own properties
suyashghuge: We're overriding those properties
Yes overriding happens if there is a conflict!
Is everyone with me now?
yes
yes
yes
yes
There are many different types of selectors. We'll be sending links. You can read about them online. After this I hope atleast selectors used in that document are clear
Okay now moving onto *properties* and *values*

*Properties* and *Values* are pretty self explanatory and need no explanation I think! Things like `color` is used to set color property is pretty obvious. Also each property can take many types of values.

The thing is you can always search the Internet for a property and the type of values it takes. So you not memorise them. Remember just the basic ones.

But selectors are more important. You have to write selectors so they suit your custom needs. That is, so they are in accordance with the HTML file you've written. So you should know different techniques used to select elements
I'll just go through some basic properties.

`color` : color takes different types of values. I mostly use hexadecimal.
For example black can be assigned as follows : 

`color : black;`
`color : #000000;`
`color : rgb(0,0,0);`

I use hexadecimal because you can easily get hexadecimal values of any color using Google's color picker.

<https://www.google.co.in/search?q=%23ffffff&oq=%23ffffff&gs_l=serp.3..35i39k1.2341.2737.0.3362.3.3.0.0.0.0.129.376.0j3.3.0....0...1.1.64.serp..0.3.376...0.M1iWv9_Zzjc>
Some other common properties are `margin` and `padding`. Learn about the differences between them. Both are used to space different elements properly on screen

So this is it for today! If you have any doubts you can always PM any of us!

root.text: The alt attribute provides an alternate text for an image, if the user for some reason cannot view it (because of slow connection, an error in the src attribute, or if the user uses a screen reader). (Not that important)
